    Module 1 Introduction to R Module 2 Basic of R Module 3 Constructing Workflow Exercise 1

    Exercise 1

    2023-04-07

    Exercise1.Rmd

    Exercise 1

    Install and load library dplyr.

    1. Call help for function arrange of dplyr


    Exercise 2

    Create a variable called myVar and assign it to \(30\)

    1. What data type is myVar? (Use a function to check)
    2. Convert myVar to a different data type


    Exercise 3

    Create a new variable called my_num tha contains 6 numbers

    1. Multiply my_num by 4


    Exercise 4

    Create a second variable called my_char that contains 5 character strings


    Exercise 5

    Combine the two variables that my_num and my_char into a variable called both

    1. What is the length of both
    2. Divide both by 3, what happens?


    Exercise 6

    Create a vector with elements 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and call it x


    Exercise 7

    Create another vector with elements 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 and call it y


    Exercise 8

    What happens if you try to add x and y together? Why?

    1. Add x and y together
    2. Multiply x and y together. Pay attention to how R performs operations on vectors of the same length
    3. What happens if x and y have different length?


    Exercise 9

    Now create a vector with elements “aa”, “bb”, “cc”, “dd”, “kk” and call it z

    1. What happens if you try to add x or y with z together
    2. Why does the error comes up? (Hint: data types)


    Exercise 10

    If x <- c("ww", "ee", "ff", "uu", "kk"), what is the output for x[c(2,3)]?

    1. Can you subset x in another way and get the same output?


    Exercise 11

    If x <- c("ss", "aa", "ff", "kk", "bb"), what will be the third value in the index vector operation x[c(2,4,4)]?


    Exercise 12

    Assign fname <- "James" and lname <- "Bond",

    1. Produce the output James Bond using a line of code (Hint: use paste())


    Exercise 13

    Create two character vectors:

    • Names <- c("John", "Andrew", "Thomas") and
    • Designation <- c("Manager", "Project Head", "Marketing Head").
    1. Write some R code to obtain the following output (Hint: check help page the function you used to create a data frame):
    #>       Names Designation
#> 1          John Manager
#> 2   Andrew Project Head
#> 3 Thomas Marketing Head


    Exercise 14

    Create the following data frame, and call it Employees

    #>      Names Age Height Weight Sex
#> 1     Alex  25    177     57   F
#> 2    Lilly  31    163     69   F
#> 3     Mark  23    190     83   M
#> 4   Oliver  52    179     75   M
#> 5   Martha  76    163     70   F
#> 6    Lucas  49    183     83   M
#> 7 Caroline  26    164     53   F
    1. Extract specific column from a data frame
    2. Extract 3rd and 5th rows with 1st and 3rd columns
    3. Add a new column and call it Education, where everyone has an education status of HS
    4. Add new row called Louis
    5. Make Sex column into a factor. How many factor levels are in the columns?


    Exercise 15

    Create the data frame below and call it Working (make sure you import the variable Working as character and not factor).

    #>      Names Working
#> 1     Alex     Yes
#> 2    Lilly      No
#> 3     Mark      No
#> 4   Oliver     Yes
#> 5   Martha     Yes
#> 6    Lucas      No
#> 7 Caroline     Yes
    1. Add this data frame column-wise to the previous one.
    2. How many rows and columns does the new data frame have?
    3. What class of data is in each column?


    Using the iris dataset in R

    Exercise 16

    Extract Sepal.Length from the iris dataset and call the resulting vector mysepal

    1. Get the summation, mean, median, max and min of mysepal
    2. Get the summary of mysepal


    Exercise 17

    Get all rows of Species versivcolor in a new data frame. Call this data frame: iris.vers


    Exercise 18

    Get a vector called sepal.dif with the difference between Sepal.Length and Sepal.Width of versicolor plants


    Exercise 19

    Update (add) iris.vers with the new column sepal.dif


    Exercise 20

    How many observations in iris gave a Sepal.Length greater or equal 5?


    Using the mtcars dataset in R

    Exercise 21

    Check to see if you have the mtcars dataset by entering the command mtcars.

    1. What class is mtcars?


    Exercise 22

    How many observations (rows) and variables (columns) are in the mtcars dataset?


    Exercise 23

    Perform an descriptive analysis on the mtcars dataset (Hint: data types of columns, mean, median, …).

    1. How many unique values in cyl, vs, am, gear, and carb (Hint: use unique())?


    Exercise 24

    Get the first 9 observations of mtcars.

    1. Get the last 9 observations of mtcars
    2. Get the 10th to 15th, 24th to 26th, and 28th to 32th observations of mtcars
    3. Subset a data frame of the 15th to 25th observations of hp, drat, and qsec
    4. Subset the value of the 10th to 18th observations of mpg, cyl, and disp


    Exercise 25

    Create s subset cars that only contains the columns: wt, qsec, and hp and assign this object to carsSub

    1. What are the dimensions of carsSub
    2. Extract the first 2 variables of the first 2 observations of carsSub
